cyclone.name: ELSA
cyclone.current_location: about 110 mi (175 km) SE of Isla Beata, Dominican Republic
cyclone.trajectory: Moving west-northwest across Hispaniola today, then near Jamaica and eastern Cuba Sunday, crossing central/western Cuba Monday and emerging into the Florida Straits before curving northwest toward the eastern Gulf and the Florida Peninsula/SE U.S.
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: western Florida peninsula (near the Tampa–Cedar Key area)

port.name: Port of Palm Beach District, FL

weather_observation.watch_coast: Hurricane and tropical-storm watches confined to parts of Cuba and the Caribbean; none issued for Florida yet
weather_observation.warning_coast: Current warnings limited to southern Hispaniola, Jamaica and parts of Cuba—not Florida
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Entire Florida Peninsula and Keys likely to experience squalls, heavy rain and possible tropical-storm-force winds early next week
weather_observation.rain_fall_above_4_inch: Likely (isolated totals up to 6 inches possible)
weather_observation.storm_surge_above_3_feet: Unlikely at this time (no surge guidance issued for southeast FL yet)
weather_observation.wind: 20% chance of sustained tropical-storm-force (≥34 kt) winds beginning late Monday night into Tuesday; strongest gusts most likely if Elsa tracks closer to the east coast.
weather_observation.storm_surge: None indicated for Palm Beach at this advisory, greatest surge risk on Cuba and later Florida Gulf coast.
weather_observation.rainfall: Bands may bring 2–4 inches with local 6-inch totals, causing ponding on-dock, reduced visibility and cargo-handling delays.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Brief tornadoes possible in outer rain bands; hazardous seas and rip currents beginning Monday.
